9. Pay attention to foreshortening and diminishing,
as one sees in life; I say to you,
it is not only architecture that requires precise rules.
You still need to know how to place
your eye or point correctly on the Horizon,
that is, on the uppermost line of the water,
All that is below is seen above,
And the rest can be seen shifted from below.
right-middleOn the need to understand foreshortening.
right-middleThe Horizon is where the Sky and water part, or sometimes where the sky and ground part.

10. As for the background, it can never be too faint,
Not as pale in the depth below as it is higher up.
considering the thickening of the Air, dense with blue,
which come between our gaze and the distance,
obscuring our attempts at keen understanding.
On occasion, here and there,
as if the Sun were shining through the clouds,
one can bring out Cities and Mountains.
right-middleOn shadowing Mountains and Cities with clouds, and revealing the clouds in the water.

11. Next to this one should also darken,
sometimes completely, sometimes half, the Cities
shadowed by clouds, and still make sure not to miss
the water mirroring the colors in the sky.
Following the old custom, divide the sky in two,
it is very good sometimes to let it gently melt at the bottom,
as well as, sometimes, the glow of the sun.

12. The exceptions are periods of harsh winds
when the Sea is agitated and streams become fountains.
I am sometimes led to marvel
At how full of thunder and lightning
Apelles’ colors are, being so few.
Now they are numerous and pure,
Suitable for depicting such unusual things.
Why does the desire to imitate them not impel us too?
right-middleApelles painted with a mere four colors, as Pliny says, and created lightning, thunder and other such things; we, with so many more colors, must also wish to pursue nature in its entirety.

div.ab:
13. On occasion, paint the water’s raging surface,
Stirred by the messenger of Eolus;
create black thunderstorms, threatening and monstrous,
and crooked bolts of lightning, through the wild tempest
in the blackened sky, arriving in a flood
from the hand of the highest of the Gods,
so that all mortal Soul-bearing creatures
appear driven to fear from such things.
right-middleOn painting thunderstorms, storms at sea, thunder and lightning.

14. One should also attempt with colors
to make snow, hail, and cloudburst,
sleet, frost, and gloomy, smothering mist.
